name: Pregnancy Risk in Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
description: Pregnancy in vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome carries extremely high maternal mortality risk, estimated at 5-12% per pregnancy. The major risks are uterine rupture, arterial rupture/dissection, and bowel perforation. Unlike Marfan syndrome, there is no aortic diameter threshold that can stratify risk - rupture occurs unpredictably. Extensive preconception counseling is essential, and some experts consider pregnancy relatively contraindicated. If pregnancy occurs, multidisciplinary management at a specialized center is mandatory.

timing.postpartum: Risk continues for weeks after delivery

uterine_rupture.mechanism: Defective type III collagen in uterine wall
uterine_rupture.timing: Can occur in any trimester, more common in third trimester and labor
uterine_rupture.presentation: Abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, fetal distress, shock
uterine_rupture.surgical_challenge: Uterine tissue does not hold sutures

arterial_rupture.mechanism: Increased blood volume and cardiac output stresses fragile vessels

aortic_dissection.risk: Elevated, though less than arterial rupture

delivery_complications.lacerations: Vaginal and cervical tears with poor healing

discussion_points.no_safe_threshold: Unlike Marfan, no diameter/measurement that predicts safety
discussion_points.inheritance: 50% chance of passing condition to child
discussion_points.limited_interventions: Surgery if complications is extremely high-risk

alternatives_to_biological_pregnancy: If proceeding: IVF with preimplantation genetic diagnosis to avoid transmission

individualized_view.position: Patient autonomy with fully informed consent
individualized_view.rationale: Some patients accept risks after counseling

common_ground.agreement: Extensive counseling, informed consent, multidisciplinary care if proceeding

monitoring.symptoms: Immediate evaluation of any pain (chest, abdominal, back)

imaging.for_symptoms: Immediate imaging for any concerning symptoms

delivery_planning.timing: Aim for 34-37 weeks to reduce exposure time
delivery_planning.location: Tertiary center with immediate surgical capability
delivery_planning.blood_products: Type and screen, blood products readily available
delivery_planning.anesthesia: Neuraxial preferred if possible (avoids airway manipulation)
delivery_planning.surgical_backup: Vascular and general surgery on standby

postpartum_considerations.continued_risk: Risk persists for weeks after delivery

fetal_considerations.neonatal: Affected neonate needs follow-up (though pediatric events less common)

clinical_pearls: vEDS pregnancy mortality is 5-12% - 25-50x higher than Marfan
No diameter threshold predicts safety - rupture is unpredictable
Some experts consider pregnancy relatively contraindicated in vEDS
If proceeding: multidisciplinary care, tertiary center, early delivery planned
learning_objectives: Quantify the maternal mortality risk of pregnancy in vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
Outline preconception counseling elements for women with vEDS
Compare pregnancy risk in vEDS versus Marfan syndrome
